docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The "dollar value" of our exports in 1933 increased 4 per cent over those for the preceding year, to a total of $1,675,000,000, but our exports were below those of Great Britain for the first time since 1914, the Commerce...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The "dollar value" of our exports in 1933 increased 4 per cent over those for the preceding year, to a total of $1,675,000,000, but our exports were below those of Great Britain for the first time since 1914, the Commerce Department announced today.

headline.main: PRICE GAINS MADE 1933 EXPORTS RISE; Increase Over 1932 Was 4% in Dollar Value, but Volume Was Unchanged. TOTAL BELOW BRITAIN'S For the First Time in 19 Years -- Our Exports Dropped 19% Below 1932 on Gold Basis.

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, April 13. -- Dark, heavy storm clouds are gathering again on the South American horizon. The Leticia dispute between Colombia and Peru threatens soon to give this continent its second war. The Chaco war between Bolivia and Paraguay is...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, April 13. -- Dark, heavy storm clouds are gathering again on the South American horizon. The Leticia dispute between Colombia and Peru threatens soon to give this continent its second war. The Chaco war between Bolivia and Paraguay is entering its third Winter with no indications of peace in the near future.

headline.main: Heavy Storm Clouds Gather Over Most of South America; Colombia and Peru, Bolivia and Paraguay Still at Odds -- Brazil Restive Over Presidency -- Uruguay Finds Plot. STORMS GATHERING IN SOUTH AMERICA

byline.original: By JOHN G. WHITE.Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES.By JOHN G. WHITE

docs.snippet: THE Chaco war with Bolivia dominates every aspect of life in Paraguay today. Entering the country by train, one has no difficulty in realizing that it is a nation at war. The first large town is Encarnacion. In its station is this sign:

headline.main: PARAGUAY BLIGHTED BY THE CHACO WAR; One Man Out of Five Is in the Army and Its Activities Absorb the Civilian

headline.main: OUR SOUTH AMERICAN TRADE FACES MANY NEW OBSTACLES; The Latin Republics Are Restricting Their Imports, Building Up Industries and 'Buying From Those Who Buy From Them'

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, April 15. -- The Uruguayan Government has established strict censorship in an effort to ameliorate the state of alarm throughout the country as next Thursday's election approaches. President Gabriel Terra has issued a decree prohibiting...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, April 15. -- The Uruguayan Government has established strict censorship in an effort to ameliorate the state of alarm throughout the country as next Thursday's election approaches. President Gabriel Terra has issued a decree prohibiting newspapers and broadcasting stations from making any mention of a possible revolution or of the government's measures to maintain order under penalty of immediate closure.
docs.abstract: Revolt feared; censorship imposed as election day nears

headline.main: URUGUAY IS FEARFUL OF REVOLT THIS WEEK; President Terra Imposes Press and Radio Censorship as Election Day Nears.

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES
